hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Zafar ibn al-Harith: Mu'awiyyah sent me to Aisha, and she said: 'There is no harm in delaying the evening prayer until midnight.'

narrators.name: Ibn al-Mubarak
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: From (potentially indirect, but from very reliable narrator)
narrators.alternative_names: Abdullah ibn al-Mubarak, Abu Abd al-Rahman

narrators.name: Isa ibn Umar
reliabilityIssues: saduq grade - some errors in narration

narrators.name: Jahhasha ibn al-Ala'
narrators.full_name: Jahhasha ibn al-Ala' al-Thaqafi (identity requires verification)

narrators.name: Aisha bint Abi Bakr
narrators.alternative_names: Mother of the Believers, Aisha al-Siddiqah

chainIssues: First narrator Muhammad ibn Muqatil is unknown (Majhul) and appears only as the immediate narrator to the compiler
Ibn al-Mubarak, though highly reliable, narrates using 'an which creates slight ambiguity in connection
Jahhasha ibn al-Ala' has uncertain identity status (Majhul)
Zafar ibn al-Harith is also unknown (Majhul) with only 'an transmission
Multiple majhul narrators in middle positions of chain weaken overall reliability
Transmission alternates between ambiguous ('an) and explicit (sami'u, akhbarana) terms
Despite Ibn al-Mubarak's reliability, the chain quality is compromised by unknown narrators

potential_issues.issue: First narrator (Muhammad ibn Muqatil) is unknown (Majhul al-Ayn or al-Hal)
potential_issues.impact: Isolated first narrator from whom only the compiler heard directly weakens the chain. The reliability of Muhammad ibn Muqatil is undocumented

potential_issues.issue: Jahhasha ibn al-Ala' is unknown (Majhul) with ambiguous transmission term 'sami'u' context
potential_issues.impact: Unknown narrators in middle positions of isnad create weaknesses in chain continuity

potential_issues.issue: Zafar ibn al-Harith is unknown (Majhul) narrating from Aisha using 'an
potential_issues.impact: Ambiguous transmission from unknown narrator to companion figure raises questions about actual meeting and direct hearing

potential_issues.issue: Ibn al-Mubarak (highly reliable) uses 'an from Ibn al-Muqatil (unknown)
potential_issues.impact: While Ibn al-Mubarak's reliability is established, his use of 'an from an unknown source prevents confirmation of the connection. Ibn al-Mubarak was meticulous but this ambiguity remains

potential_issues.issue: Multiple majhul narrators in single chain: Muhammad ibn Muqatil, Jahhasha, and Zafar
potential_issues.impact: Concentration of unknown narrators in one chain significantly weakens authenticity assessment

potential_issues.issue: Statement is from Aisha (companion) not from Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: This is a mawquf hadith (stopped at companion), not marfu' (attributed to Prophet). This reflects Aisha's personal ruling/opinion on prayer timing

Topics: Permissibility of delaying Isha until midnight

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Um Hani: The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said to her, 'Glorify Allah one hundred times, equivalent to the freeing of one hundred slaves.'

narrators.name: Thabit
narrators.alternative_names: محمد بن عمر بن أبي سلمة

narrators.name: Mawla of Um Hani
narrators.full_name: The mawla (freed slave) of Um Hani (specific name not provided in text)
reliabilityIssues: only known by relationship to Um Hani

narrators.name: Um Hani
narrators.full_name: Um Hani bint Abi Talib (companion of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ)
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: From (potentially indirect, but from reliable companion)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: First narrator (Musa) identity unclear - data shows narrator_id 7721 as Muhammad ibn Ziyad but text uses 'Musa'
Second narrator (Jarthuma) identity mismatch - database indicates Hakim ibn Salman (13559) but text clearly states Jarthuma
Third narrator (Thabit) identity uncertain - database shows Muhammad ibn Umar (2009) but text states Thabit
Fourth narrator is anonymous (mawla of Um Hani) - classified as Majhul al-Ayn since only one chain preserved
Connection from Mawla to Um Hani uses both direct narrative term and 'an' which creates slight ambiguity
Direct transmission terms (sami'tu, hadathani) used in first chain indicate good documentation of hearing

narrators.name: Musa ibn Khalf
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: He narrated to us (abbreviated direct narration)

narrators.name: Asim ibn Bahdala
narrators.full_name: Asim ibn Bahdala al-Kufi (likely Asim al-Ahwal, known mudallis)
reliabilityIssues: using 'an' which is problematic for mudallis

narrators.name: Abu Salih
narrators.full_name: Abu Salih (the mawla of Um Hani)

narrators.name: Um Hani
narrators.full_name: Um Hani bint Abi Talib (companion of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ)

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Identity mismatch between text and database for Abdul-Salam ibn Mutahhar - database shows Suwayd ibn Amr (4544)
Musa ibn Khalf identity uncertain - database shows Muhammad ibn Salem (7731)
Asim ibn Bahdala narrates using 'an and is a known mudallis (category 3), which significantly weakens this chain
Abu Salih narrates using 'an from Um Hani, introducing further ambiguity
Second chain is generally weaker than the first due to multiple 'an transmissions and mudallis involvement

potential_issues.issue: Critical data quality issue: Narrator names in Arabic text do not match narrator IDs in database metadata
potential_issues.impact: The reliability grades assigned are based on the actual names in the historical text, not the database IDs which appear to be incorrectly mapped

potential_issues.issue: First chain contains anonymous narrator (mawla of Um Hani) - Majhul al-Ayn status
potential_issues.impact: This introduces weakness into the first chain as anonymous narrators are problematic in hadith transmission. However, the mawla is from a known companion household

potential_issues.issue: Second chain contains Asim ibn Bahdala who is a known mudallis (category 3) and uses 'an transmission
potential_issues.impact: According to hadith sciences methodology, mudallis narrators reporting with 'an' instead of direct terms (hadathana/sami'tu) significantly reduces chain reliability. This chain cannot be considered authentic without explicit hearing statement

potential_issues.issue: Editor's note at end of text states 'wala yassih hadha an um hani' (this is not authentic from Um Hani)
potential_issues.impact: The source document itself indicates critical doubts about this hadith's authenticity, particularly regarding the transmission from Um Hani. This is an explicit authenticity rejection by the original source compiler

potential_issues.issue: Transmission terminology inconsistency between chains
potential_issues.impact: First chain uses stronger direct terms (sami'tu, hadathani) while second chain relies heavily on 'an' from unreliable narrators. This fundamental difference suggests the first chain is more reliable if the narrator identities are correct

Topics: Dialogue between Prophet Muhammad ﷺ and Um Hani

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aisha: Ali is the most knowledgeable of the people regarding the Sunnah.

narrators.name: Ali ibn Abi Talib
narrators.full_name: Ali ibn Abi Talib al-Qurashi (caller/narrator reporting this)

narrators.name: Yahya ibn al-Yamani
narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn al-Yamani (or Yahya ibn Zakariya al-Yamani)

narrators.name: Sufyan
narrators.transmissionTermMeaning: From (potentially indirect, but from very reliable narrator)

narrators.name: Ata' ibn Abi Rabah
narrators.full_name: Ata' ibn Abi Rabah (freedman of Abdullah ibn Umar)

narrators.name: Aisha bint Abi Bakr
narrators.full_name: Aisha bint Abu Bakr al-Siddiq (Mother of the Believers)

chainIssues: First narrator (Ali as immediate reporter) has uncertain reliability
Yahya ibn al-Yamani narrates with explicit hadathana (direct) term
Sufyan uses 'an from Yahya - ambiguous connection despite Sufyan's reliability
Jahdab al-Taymi is relatively weak (La Ba'sa Bihi) with 'an transmission
Ata' uses explicit sami'tu (heard) which strengthens connection from Jahdab
Transmission to companion Aisha is implied but not explicit
Multiple reliability gaps in middle of chain

potential_issues.issue: First narrator position ambiguous - Ali appears as 'qala lana' (said to us) rather than standard hadith narrator
potential_issues.impact: Unclear whether Ali is making the initial report or if there's another layer of transmission not explicitly stated

potential_issues.issue: Jahdab al-Taymi (La Ba'sa Bihi) narrates with 'an from Sufyan
potential_issues.impact: While not explicitly weak (daif), Jahdab's reliability is limited and 'an transmission creates ambiguity

potential_issues.issue: Multiple chains exist with confusing variants mentioned in editor notes
potential_issues.impact: Editor notes indicate uncertainty about relationship between variant chains, suggesting authentication difficulties

potential_issues.issue: Some alternative chains mentioned as problematic - Ibn Fudail chain involves unknown/weak narrators
potential_issues.impact: Presence of weak variant chains suggests core hadith also faces reliability questions

potential_issues.issue: This is mawquf (statement from companion Aisha) not marfu' (attributed to Prophet)
potential_issues.impact: Limits evidential value as it represents Aisha's opinion/knowledge, not necessarily prophetic guidance

Topics: Ali's knowledge and understanding of the Sunnah
Aisha's assessment of Ali's Islamic scholarship
Companion evaluation of Ali's jurisprudential expertise
